column3: Question
column4: Answer 1
column5: Answer 2
column6: Answer 3

column3: What is the most commonly used way by corporates to maximize shareholders value
column4: M&A
column5: Disposal/spin-off….
column6: Improve operating performance (price/ costs/ volume…)

column3: What is the difference between "expansionary" M&A and "restructuring" M&A?
column4: Expansionary M&A is the fact of acquiring companies or merging with them vs restructuring is restructuring the existing businesses
column5: Expansionary M&A is the fact of acquiring companies or merging with them vs restructuring is more of reducing the size of the business by disposing partially or totally some divisions
column6: Expansionary M&A is the fact of acquiring companies or merging with them vs restructuring is doing expansionary M&A but with always the aim of restructuring the businesses you buy

column3: What is the difference between an acquisition and a merger?
column4: In an acquisition/ you are buying shares of a company or its assets and the acquirer and target stay legally separated; in a merger/ the buyer absorbs the target (target legally disappears) or a new entity is created that encompasses the buyer and the target
column5: In an acquisition/ you are buying assets of a company  and the acquirer and target stay legally separated; in a merger/ the buyer absorbs the target (target legally disappears)
column6: There is no difference. There are only two different terminologies used/ one most in the US and the other mostly in Europe

column3: How is called an acquisition of assets in exchange of shares?
column4: A merger
column5: A contribution of assets
column6: A spin-off

column3: What is a mixed offer?
column4: An offer of less than 100% of a target
column5: An offer made by 2 or more buyers for a single asset
column6: An offer made of cash and shares of the buyer

column3: What is the difference in terms of economic outcome (entity post deal) between a cash/  a share deal and a mixed offer?
column4: The cash deal is easier to deal with post deal
column5: The share deal creates some governance problem
column6: No difference

column3: What are the main characteristics of a cash offer?
column4: The price is fixed/ the selling shareholders go away but are taxed on the sale
column5: The price is variable/ the selling shareholders go away but are taxed on the sale
column6: The price is fixed/ the selling shareholders go away but are not taxed on the sale

column3: What are the main characteristics of a share offer?
column4: The price is given on relative basis/ usually tax free for both parties/ can be found mainly for small deals usually
column5: The price is fixed/ usually tax free for both parties/ can be found mainly for large deals
column6: The price is given on relative basis/ usually tax free for both parties/ can be found mainly  for large deals

column3: What are the main characteristics of asset contributions?
column4: Only part of assets (and no liabilities) are transfered/ transaction paid in shares/ usually tax free
column5: Only part of assets (and liabilities) are transfered/ transaction paid in shares/ usually tax free
column6: Only part of assets (and liabilities) are transfered/ transaction paid in shares/ usually taxed on capital gain

column3: In a cash deal/ how is the statutory account balance sheet of the buyer changing?
column4: On the liability side/ the debt increases by the price paid/ and for all other liability and asset accounts you add up all the accounts of the target plus goodwill if any
column5: On the liability side/ the debt increases by the price paid/ and you add on the asset side the value paid for the share of the target (financial investment)
column6: On the liability side/ the debt increases by the price paid/ and for all other liability and asset accounts you add up all the accounts of the target (no goodwill)

column3: In a cash deal/ what type of risk(s) the buyer is taking?
column4: It is taking both operational and financial risk (increased leverage)
column5: It is taking mostly operational risk as it will be alone to run the combined business and deliver the synergies
column6: It is mostly taking the financial risk as the price paid for the equity plus the debt assumed will increase the leverage

column3: How to decrease the financial risk of the buyer in a cash deal?
column4: By refinancing the debt of the target
column5: By doing a capital increase on the buyer side after the acquisition
column6: By hedging the debt raised as well as the foreign exchange risk

column3: In case of cash deal/ what restrictions can lending banks put in place?
column4: Covenants (Net Debt/EBITDA limit)/ clause of repayment in case of change of control/ limits on Capex or Dividends
column5: Limitations on Net Debt /EBITDA only
column6: Limitations on dividends only

column3: In a cash deal how do you compute the pro-forma net income (ie net income of the buyer post deal)
column4: You sum up the net income of the buyer and the target and add the synergies post tax
column5: You sum up the net income of the buyer and the target/ deduct the interest expense coming from the debt raised (to pay for the target's equity) and add the synergies post tax
column6: You sum up the net income of the buyer and the target/ deduct the interest expense coming from the debt raised (to pay for the target's equity)/ add tax benefit of these new interest expense and add the synergies post tax

column3: What is the rule of thumb to know if a cash deal will be EPS accretive?
column4: 1 / cost of acquisition debt after tax > P/E of target at the price paid
column5: 1 / cost of acquisition debt after tax < P/E of target at the price paid
column6: 1 / cost of acquisition debt after tax < P/E of target

column3: Is an EPS accretive deal creating value for buyer's shareholders? Why?
column4: Yes. If EPS increases/ assuming P/E is constant/ the share price will increase
column5: Yes. As shareholders are focusing on how much earnings they get per share. Therefore if EPS increases/ there will be more value for them
column6: No. Even though EPS increases/ we do not know what the P/E will do. Therefore/ we cannot predict the share price evolution this way

column3: In a cash deal/ is the shareholders equity of the buyer affected?
column4: No as no new shares created
column5: Yes as you need to add the target's shareholders equity
column6: Yes as the company becomes bigger

column3: What are synergies to break even?
column4: They are the synergies needed for the buyer's shareholders to get value creation
column5: They are the synergies needed to be EPS neutral in case the deal is EPS dilutive
column6: They are the synergies needed to be EPS neutral in case the deal is EPS dilutive and that there is already synergies in the deal

column3: What is the formula to compute the synergies to break even?
column4: (Buyer's EPS - Pro forma EPS) x Pro forma number of shares / (1 - tax rate)
column5: (Buyer's EPS - Pro forma EPS) x  (1 - tax rate) / Pro forma number of shares
column6: (Pro Forma EPS - Buyer's EPS) x  (1 - tax rate) / Pro forma number of shares

column3: What is the name of the IFRS that enables you to compute goodwill?
column4: Purchase Price Parity (IFRS 6)
column5: Purchase Price allocation (IFRS 3)
column6: Goodwill creation (IFRS 3)

column3: How to compute goodwill in a deal?
column4: Price paid for the Target's equity minus Target's shareholders equity (group share) minus any new identifiable intangible to be created on Target's side
column5: Price paid for the Target's equity minus Target's shareholders equity (group) minus any new identifiable intangible to be created on Target's side
column6: Price paid for the Target's enterprise value minus Target's shareholders equity (group) minus any new identifiable intangible to be created on Target's side

column3: If we assume an acquisition with a PF balance sheet = buyer's B/S + target's B/S + Adjustments/ what are these adjustments?
column4: + target's shareholders equity + acquisition debt + new goodwill created - target's goodwill
column5: - target's shareholders equity + acquisition debt + new goodwill created - target's goodwill
column6: - target's shareholders equity + acquisition debt + target's goodwill

column3: If we assume an acquisition with a PF balance sheet = buyer's B/S + target's B/S + Adjustments/ what are these adjustments?
column4: + target's shareholders equity + acquisition debt + new goodwill created - target's goodwill
column5: - target's shareholders equity + acquisition debt + cash used to pay target's shareholders + new goodwill created - target's goodwill
column6: - target's shareholders equity + acquisition debt - cash used to pay target's shareholders + new goodwill created - target's goodwill

column3: As a buyer/ in a cash deal/ what is true here?
column4: The price you pay is in absolute terms/ you will ask representation and warranties to the seller as it goes away/ you keep all the upside
column5: The price you pay is in absolute terms/ you make only an industrial bet/ you will ask representation and warranties to the seller as it goes away
column6: The price you pay is on relative terms/ you will ask representation and warranties to the seller as it goes away/ you keep all the upside

column3: As a seller/ in a cash deal/ what is true here?
column4: You receive cash/ pay no taxes/ provide representation & warranties to the buyer/ do not have any upside in the deal
column5: You receive cash/ pay taxes/ provide representation & warranties to the buyer/ do not have any upside in the deal
column6: You receive cash/ pay taxes/ provide representation & warranties to the buyer/ have a limited upside in the combined business

column3: How can be seen a share deal from the point of view of the selling shareholders?
column4: The selling shareholders are buyers of the new group (ie buyer + target)
column5: The selling shareholders are buying in the target's business
column6: The selling shareholders are buying in the target's equity

column3: What are the other names of a share deal?
column4: Share for share exchange/ share swap
column5: Share for cash exchange
column6: Share contributions

column3: How to compute the exchange ratio (nb of buyer's shares per target's share) in a share deal?
column4: Target equity value "agreed"  / Buyer equity value "agreed" x target number of share / buyer number of shares
column5: Target market capitalization  / Buyer equity value x buyer number of share / target number of shares
column6: Target equity value "agreed"  / Buyer equity value "agreed" x buyer number of share / target number of shares

column3: How does the statutory account balance sheet of the buyer change in case of a share deal?
column4: All assets and liabilitiy accounts increase by the amount of the target's/ goodwill is added and the shareholders equity increases by the enterprise value paid
column5: Fixed assets increase by the value paid for the target shares bought and the shareholders equity increases by the same amount
column6: Fixed assets increase by the book value of the target shares bought and the shareholders equity increases by the same amount

column3: How to determine the buyer's % ownership in the combined business in a share deal?
column4: Buyer's market capitalization / Target's market capitalization
column5: Buyer's market capitalization / (Target's + Buyer's) market capitalization
column6: Buyer's equity value agreed / (Target's + Buyer's) equity value agreed

column3: How to determine the equity value of the buyer and the target that will be used to determine the exchange ratio?
column4: As it is a change of control deal/ transaction comparables will be used
column5: Only standalone valuation methods will be used
column6: Only DCF will be used

column3: How to take into account the synergies to determine the equity value of the buyer and the target that will be used to determine the exchange ratio?
column4: Need to split 50/50
column5: Usually give more to the buyer than the target
column6: Do not take them into account here

column3: From a structuring standpoint/ how does a share deal work?
column4: The buyer does a reserved capital increase for the target's shareholders
column5: The buyer does a reserved capital increase to finance the deal
column6: The buyer and the target create a new legal entity to manage the combined entities

column3: What is the voting process on the buyer side in case of a share deal?
column4: 2/3 of buyer's shareholders have to vote for the share deal and have to approve the value of the Target's equity chosen
column5: 75% of buyer's shareholders have to vote for the share deal and have to approve the value of the Target's equity chosen
column6: 2/3 of buyer's shareholders have to vote for the share deal and have to approve the value of the Target's and Buyer's equity chosen

column3: What classical clauses could you find in a shareholders agreement?
column4: Pre-emptive rights/ anti-dilutive provisions/ drag-long/tag-long/ lock-up provision
column5: Representations & warranties/ anti-dilutive provisions/ drag-long/tag-long/ lock-up provision
column6: Pre-emptive rights/ anti-dilutive provisions/ dividend restrictions/ lock-up provision

column3: What is a drag-along right?
column4:
If the majority shareholder wants to sell (>75% usually) his shares/ minority shareholders have to
do so (same price/same terms as Shareholder)
column5:
If majority shareholder wants to sell his shares/ minority shareholders have the right to do the
same (same price/terms/ same proportion as Shareholder)
column6: If the majority shareholder wants to sell (>75% usually) his shares/ minority shareholders can do the same (same price/same terms as Shareholder)

column3: What is a tag-along right?
column4:
If the majority shareholder wants to sell (>75% usually) his shares/ minority shareholders have to
do so (same price/same terms as Shareholder)
column5:
If majority shareholder wants to sell his shares/ minority shareholders have the right to do the
same (same price/terms/ same proportion as Shareholder)
column6: If the majority shareholder wants to sell (>75% usually) his shares/ minority shareholders can do the same (same price/same terms as Shareholder)

column3: What is an anti-dilutive provision?
column4: It enables company to keep a positive EPS
column5: It enables some shareholders to keep the same % ownership whatever happens
column6:
It is a compensation (cash or shares) given to minority shareholders (<33%) in case of new shares issued in the future (as they
cannot block such capital increase) at a lower price than the one at which they bought the shares

column3: What is a deadlock provision?
column4: It is a provision that forces a shareholder to exit
column5: It is a provision that helps to exit one of the shareholders to solve a governance problem (e.g. key objective not reached)
column6: It is a provision that give the right to the majority shareholder to buy out the stake of the minority shareholders

column3: Please give an example of deadlock provision mechanism?
column4: A combination of (1) call option given by Mino to Majo on Mino stake and (2) put option given by Majo to Mino on Mino stake → Same strike price (e.g. the strike price can be based on a given multiple or on entering valuation with compounded interest rate)
column5: A combination of (1) put option given by Mino to Majo on Mino stake and (2) call option given by Majo to Mino on Mino stake → Same strike price (e.g. the strike price can be based on a given multiple or on entering valuation with compounded interest rate)
column6: A combination of (1) call option given by Mino to Majo on Mino stake and (2) put option given by Majo to Mino on Mino stake → different strike price that favor the Maj shareholder

column3: What is a pre-emptive right in a shareholders agreeement?
column4: A right offered to a specific shareholder to buy the shares of other shareholders at a discount in case they wish to sell
column5: An obligation that the majority shareholder has to buy the shares of the minority shareholders if it wants to sell
column6:
Often a right in favor of Majority shareholder on the shares tendered by Minority shareholders in
case they are willing to sell them down the road

column3: How to compute the pro-forma net income in case of a share deal?
column4: Net income buyer + net income target + synergies post tax
column5: Net income buyer + net income target + synergies post tax + interest expense post tax on new debt
column6: Net income buyer + net income target + synergies post tax + dividend on new shares issued

column3: How to compute the number of shares pro-forma to compute the EPS  in case of a share deal?
column4: Equal to the number of shares of the buyer
column5: Number of shares of the buyer + number of shares of the target
column6: Number of shares of the buyer + equity value paid for the target / buyer's share price

column3: What is the rule of thumb to know if a share deal is EPS accretive?
column4: P/E of acquirer > P/E of target
column5: P/E of acquirer > P/E of target at acquisition price
column6: P/E of acquirer < P/E of target at acquisition price

column3: How to compute the PF shareholders equity (SHE) in the B/S after a share deal?
column4: Buyer's SHE + Target's SHE
column5: Buyer's SHE + Equity value paid
column6: Buyer's SHE - Target's SHE + Equity value paid

column3: What are the pros/cons of a share deal for a buyer?
column4: Valuation of target viewed on a relative basis (better if buyer's well valued vs Target)/ complex process/ sharing of risk/ control and therefore upside
column5: Valuation of target viewed on an absolute basis/ complex process/ sharing of risk/ control and therefore upside
column6: Valuation of target viewed on a relative basis (better if buyer's well valued vs Target)/ complex process/ sharing of risk/ control and therefore upside. Increased financial risk

column3: What are the pros/cons of a share deal for a seller?
column4: Benefit from deferred taxation/ Take most risks & synergies/ maybe forced to accept the deal in case of legal merger
column5: Gets taxed straight away/ share risks & synergies/ maybe forced to accept the deal in case of legal merger
column6: Benefit from deferred taxation/ share risks & synergies/ maybe forced to accept the deal in case of legal merger

column3: What is the difference between a legal merger and a share deal?
column4: There is no difference from an economical standpoint. From a legal standpoint/ in a legal merger the target is absorbed vs not in a share deal
column5: The legal merger is more complex and only for international deals
column6: The share deal is a first step of a legal merger

column3: What authorizations are needed in case of a legal merger
column4: Both supermajority (2/3) on the buyer and target sides
column5: Supermajority on buyer side and simple majority on target side
column6: Authorization of EU (Europe) and FTC (US)

column3: What is the difference between a legal merger and a share deal?
column4: In a legal merger/ the process will be much faster than in a classical share deal
column5: With a share deal/ you can end up having some target shareholders not accepting the deal vs that will never happen if a legal merger is voted
column6: A legal merger forces buyer's shareholders to accept the merger

column3: What are the advantages for a buyer of doing a mixed offer vs a full cash offer?
column4: Limit financial risk/ benefit from a relative higher valuation of Bidder vs. Target’s/ keep financial flexibility for future projects
column5: Increase EPS/ benefit from a relative higher valuation of Bidder vs. Target’s/ keep financial flexibility for future projects
column6: Increase value creation/ benefit from a relative higher valuation of Target vs. Bidder’s/ keep financial flexibility for future projects

column3: What are the drawbacks for a buyer of doing a mixed offer vs a full cash offer?
column4: Will share control (and expected value creation) with Target’s shareholders/ need to live with T. shareholders (shareholder agreement to be put in place)/ however may benefit from a lower price tag than cash offer
column5: Will share control (and expected value creation) with Target’s shareholders but will keep control/ may require a higher price tag than cash offer (flowback risk/ Bidder share price uncertainty)
column6: Will share control (and expected value creation) with Target’s shareholders/ need to live with T. shareholders (shareholder agreement to be put in place)/ may require a higher price tag than cash offer (flowback risk/ Bidder share price uncertainty)

column3: How to compute the PF net income in a mixed offer?
column4: Net income of Buyer + Net income of target + Synergies post tax
column5: Net income of Buyer + Net income of target + Synergies post tax - interest expense post tax of debt raised to finance the cash part of offer
column6: Net income of Buyer + Net income of target + Synergies post tax - interest expense post tax of debt raised to finance 100% of the equity of the target

column3: How to compute the PF EPS in a mixed offer?
column4: PF net income / number of shares of the buyer
column5: PF net income / (number of shares of the buyer + equity value paid / buyer share price)
column6: PF net income / (number of shares of the buyer + portion of equity value paid in shares / buyer share price)

column3: How to get the shareholders' equity (SHE) of a buyer after a mixed offer?
column4: Buyer's SHE + Target's SHE + portion of equity value paid in shares
column5: Buyer's SHE + portion of equity value paid in shares
column6: Buyer's SHE + Target's SHE + equity value of target

column3: How to get the net debt (ND) of a buyer after a mixed offer?
column4: ND buyer + ND target + equity value target
column5: ND buyer + ND target
column6: ND buyer + ND target + equity value target paid in cash

column3: What is an asset contribution?
column4: It is a purchase of some assets (and liabilities) of a company in exchange of shares of the buyer
column5: It is a purchase of all assets and liabilities of a company in exchange of shares of the buyer
column6: It is a purchase of some assets (and liabilities) of a company in exchange of cash and shares of the buyer

column3: In case of an asset contribution/ what do selling shareholders become?
column4: They take the cash and stay owner of the Target company
column5: They stay shareholders of the Target
column6: They become shareholders of the Buyer

column3: How to compute the % ownership of the buyer's shareholders after an asset contribution?
column4: Equity value of the buyer / (Equity value of the buyer + Equity value of assets/liabilities contributed)
column5: Equity value of the buyer / (Equity value of the buyer + Enterprise value of assets/liabilities contributed)
column6: Equity value of the buyer / Equity value of assets/liabilities contributed

column3: How to compute the asset accounts of a buyer after an asset contribution?
column4: Add buyer's asset and asset contributed account by account
column5: Add buyer's asset and asset contributed account by account/ and add the goodwill created
column6: Add buyer's asset and asset contributed account by account except the cash

column3: How to compute the liability accounts of a buyer after an asset contribution?
column4: Add buyer's liability contributed account by account and add to shareholders equity the equity value of net assets contributed
column5: Add buyer's liability contributed account by account and add to shareholders equity the enterprise value of net assets contributed
column6: Add buyer's liability contributed (except financial debt) account by account and add to shareholders equity the equity value of net assets contributed

column3: What is the legal process needed for an asset contribution?
column4: No specific legal process required except the agreement of both boards of directors
column5: Need supermajority vote on both side as it is a capital increase for the buyer and on target side/ need to validate the value of assets/liabilities contributed
column6: Need supermajority vote on Buyer side as it is a capital increase for the buyer + need simple majority on target side as there is a need to validate the value of assets/liabilities contributed

column3: How to compute the PF net income in case of an asset contribution?
column4: Net income buyer + Net income Target + synergies post tax
column5: Net income buyer +  Net income coming from asset/liabilities contributed + synergies post tax
column6: Net income buyer +  Net income coming from asset/liabilities contributed + synergies post tax + interest expense post tax on debt raised

column3: How to compute the PF EPS in case of an asset contribution?
column4: PF net income / number of shares of buyer
column5: PF net income / (number of shares of buyer + equity value of asset constributed / buyer share price)
column6: PF net income / (number of shares of buyer + enterprise value of asset constributed / buyer share price)

column3: What are the pros/cons for a buyer in an asset contribution?
column4: Keep the majority of  the operating/financial risk/ keep the control but looses a bit of  potential upside/ can cherry pick the assets and liabilities it buys/ considers the price of the transaction in relative terms
column5: Shares the operating/financial risk/ shares the control (dilution) and thus the potential upside/ can cherry pick the assets and liabilities it buys/ considers the price in absolute terms
column6: Shares the operating/financial risk/ shares the control (dilution) and thus the potential upside/ can cherry pick the assets and liabilities it buys/ considers the price of the transaction in relative terms

column3: What are the pros/cons for a seller in an asset contribution?
column4: Receives shares (no cash)/ can cherry pick the assets and liabilities to be contributed/ usually benefits from deferred taxation/ has to live with the buyer
column5: Receives shares and cash/ can cherry pick the assets and liabilities to be contributed/ has to live with the buyer
column6: Receives shares (no cash)/ can cherry pick the assets and liabilities to be contributed/ has to pay limited taxes

column3: What are the 2 good motives to do M&A?
column4: Good strategic fit and expected value creation (synergies or better management)
column5: Undervalued target and expected value creation (synergies or better management)
column6: Undervalued target and expected synergies

column3: what is the golden rule for an M&A deal to create value for the buyer?
column4: Premium paid + Transaction costs < PV of (synergies – cost to achieve synergies + better management impact) if we assume Target is fairly valued
column5: EPS accretive deal and increase of ROCE
column6: Increase of ROCE and higher P/E post deal

column3: What are the 2 bad reasons to do M&A?
column4: Diversification and EPS growth
column5: vertical integration and EPS growth
column6: Value creation and diversification

column3: Give examples of economy of scope
column4: Headcount reduction and cross selling
column5: Stronger and/or longer lasting competitive advantage through higher pricing power (reduced competition)/ higher switching costs/ cross-selling of products
column6: Reduction of corporate tax rate and lower Capex

column3: Give examples of economy of scale
column4: Reduction of WACC through a more optimal capital structure
column5: Headcount reduction and cross selling
column6: Cost savings on current operations (better group purchasing terms/ cut duplicated costs…)

column3: what are asset synergies?
column4: It is an improved capital efficiency leading to lower Capex+ΔWC needed for a given level of growth (eg. capacity rationalization: airline deals/ unused plant capacity)
column5: It is an improvement of the quality of assets through M&A
column6: It is a large reduction of asset and Capex to become more asset-light in term of business model

column3: Give example(s) of tax synergies
column4: Target lower tax rate than Buyer
column5: target’s tax losses carried forward/ target’s lower corporate tax rate (if tax inversion permitted)
column6: Examption of VAT taxes post M&A

column3: Can you rank synergies according to their perception by investors (ie. higher perception meaning that investors believe more in them)
column4: Economy of scale > Economy of scope > tax synergies > Financial synergies
column5: Economy of scope > Economy of scale > tax synergies > Financial synergies
column6: Economy of scale > Financial synergies > Economy of scope > tax synergies

column3: Are 'improvement of management' included in M&A synergies?
column4: Yes as they are part of the value creation
column5: Yes as they are savings for the target
column6: No as you do not need to combine buyer + target to get them (e.g. PE fund doing M&A)

column3: If a company diversifies itself through M&A/ its value will increase as WACC will decrease (ie financial synergies)
column4: True as the combined FCFF will be less risky as more diversified/ leading to a reduced WACC and then higher EV
column5: True as diversification reduces the risk of the buyer/ reducing its WACC
column6: Wrong as/ even though the WACC may decrease/ the overall 'quality' of FCFF may decrease as well/ therefore not enabling us to conclude on higher or lower EV coming from diversification

column3: What is typically M&A bankers role in advising clients on synergies?
column4: They build them bottom-up for the clients
column5: They do nothing. Only strategic consultants work on them
column6: They benchmark the global level of synergies that are expected vs comparable transactions

column3: To what does the control premium correspond to?
column4: One/ several/ part or all of the following: value increase of the Target due to a better management/ expected synergies from the combination of buyer+target/ “perceived” undervaluation of Target by the market
column5: One/ several/ part or all of the following: value increase of the Acquirer due to a better management/ expected synergies from the combination of buyer+target/ “perceived” undervaluation of Target by the market
column6: One/ several/ part or all of the following: value increase of the Acquirer due to a better management/ expected synergies from the combination of buyer+target

column3: In a M&A deal with a given Target/ are the potentially realizable synergies always the same?
column4: Yes they are as they depend on the Target characteristics
column5: No as they are different for each buyer
column6: No as they are different for each buyer and are time dependent as well

column3: How  should expected value creation be split between buyer's and target's shareholders?
column4: Always 50-50 or 60-40 (in favor of buyer) depending on negotiation
column5: Sharing will depend on the following: who has the scarce resource/ who really wants the deal to  happen/ market “rule of thumbs” (transaction multiples/ historical premium paid…)
column6: All depends on historical premium paid that will decide the % given to seller

column3: When deciding on the control premium to pay/ what is wrong ?
column4: Looking at transaction comparable
column5: Doing a DCF of target and synergies using the target wacc (leading to the max price to pay)
column6: Doing a DCF of target and synergies using the lower between acquirer and target wacc (leading to the max price to pay)

column3: What are the classical rules of thumb used to value synergies through DCF?
column4: 1/3/ 2/3/ 100% of full synergies (post tax) in yr1/ yr2/ yr3 respectively then flat level. Restructuring costs (post tax) equal to 50% of full synergies and only in yr1 and yr 2
column5: 20%/ 40%/ 60%/ 80%/ 100% of full synergies (pre tax) in yr1/ yr2/ yr3/ yr4/ yr5 respectively then flat level. Restructuring costs (pre tax) equal to 50% of full synergies and only in yr1
column6: 1/4/ 3/4/ 100% of full synergies (post tax) in yr1/ yr2/ yr3 respectively then flat level. Restructuring costs (post tax) equal to 30% of full synergies and only in yr1 and yr 2

column3: What terminal value to use when doing DCF of synergies?
column4: No terminal value after explicit period of 5-10 years
column5: Terminal value with zero or very low growth
column6: Terminal value with inflation as perpetual growth

column3: What discount rate do you use to value synergies with DCF?
column4: Use the risk free rate
column5: use the WACC of Acquirer
column6: Technically/ the WACC of the combined business but in practice/ often/ WACC of target

column3: In a cash deal/ how to compute the expected value creation that will be kept by the buyer's shareholders?
column4: Staandalone EqV target as viewed by buyer+ yearly synergy - transaction costs - target market capitalization
column5: Standalone EqV target + yearly synergy - transaction costs - target market capitalization - premium paid
column6: Standalone EqV target as viewed by buyer + PV of  synergies - transaction costs - target market capitalization - premium paid

column3: In a cash deal/ if the buyer believes that the target is overvalued by the market by 20/ what impact (if any) does it have on the  expected value creation that will be kept by the buyer's shareholders (vs Target fairly valued and assuming same premium paid)?
column4: It will make no difference
column5: It will decrease it by 20
column6: It will not change. The premium will be decreased by 20

column3: In a share deal/ how to compute the expected value creation that will be kept by the buyer's shareholders?
column4: [Standalone EqV of the Target viewed by buyer + PV of synergies - transaction costs - premium paid (embedded into the exchange ratio) – market capitalization of the Target] x % ownership of buyer in the combined business
column5: [Standalone EqV of the Target viewed by buyer + PV of synergies - transaction costs - premium paid (embedded into the exchange ratio)] x % ownership of buyer in the combined business
column6: [Standalone EqV of the Target viewed by buyer + PV of synergies - transaction costs - premium paid (embedded into the exchange ratio) – market capitalization of the Target] x % ownership of target in the combined business
